text:
This robot can launch itself from the water
into the air.

Robots like this one that can navigate over
different terrains

could help scientists collect data in
hard-to-reach places.

This leaping robot uses a solid fuel called
calcium carbide.

A small pump onboard draws water from its
surroundings, and the water then reacts with

the calcium carbide to produce combustible
acetylene gas.

When the gas is ignited, the robot flies into
the air, propelled by a jet of water and combustion products.

Once airborne, the robot can glide, up to
26 meters.

When it lands, the chamber begins to refill
with water to prepare for relaunch.

It can do this 10 times in a row before needing
to be refueled.

The Imperial College London researchers who
built the bot say it could be used to collect

data or water samples in polar regions, during
floods, or in polluted waters.
